caption_original: Shine bright like a lighthouse…er diamond?Many weather stations are remote. With the Pachena Light Station in the background, a Coast Guard helicopter near Bamfield, B.C. safely delivers our weather station technicians to their workplace, a weather station along the world famous West Coast Trail.

caption_original: Meet Lynne (l), and Barbara (r). Both women were part of the first all-female Canadian Wildlife Service research team back in , bird banding in the Arctic. years later, Barbara continues her work with CWS. This month, you will find her on Manitoulin Island counting Sandhill Cranes.
caption_cleaned: Meet Lynne Barbara women part first female Canadian Wildlife Service research team back 1975 bird banding Arctic 41 years later Barbara continues work CWS month find Manitoulin Island counting Sandhill Cranes

caption_original: “Puffin Patrol to the rescue! This young puffin (on the right), found near the Witless Bay Ecological Reserve, NL, was drawn ashore by bright lights from nearby communities at night. We band and measure the rescued puffins before releasing them back in to the ocean.” - Sabina, CWS Crew
caption_cleaned: Puffin Patrol rescue young puffin right found near Witless Bay Ecological Reserve NL drawn ashore bright lights nearby communities night band measure rescued puffins releasing back ocean Sabina CWS Crew

caption_original: “I AM A MAGICAL OWL DELIVERING A MESSAGE: HOOOOO!” A burrowing owl trying really hard to be a spooky hoot. Happy owl-ween!

caption_original: Here is a photo of the Automated Weather Station taken in the Callaghan valley near Whistler last March, while the sun was still coming up over the mountains and the hoar frost is on the snow. Automated weather stations like this one near Whistler, BC provide weather data for more accurate forecasting!
caption_cleaned: photo Automated Weather Station taken Callaghan valley near Whistler last March sun still coming mountains hoar frost snow nAutomated weather stations like one near Whistler BC provide weather data accurate forecasting

caption_original: “Approaching Sand Heads, a weather station off Vancouver Island in the Georgia Strait. Sometimes, I go on familiarization trips as a meteorologist, for example, to replace and calibrate weather sensors. To do that, I hop into a hovercraft with the Canadian Coast Guard! You’re jealous, I know! In the background, one of our monitoring technicians and three coast guards unload our equipment onto the platform.” – Cindy YU, MSC Crew
caption_cleaned: Approaching Sand Heads weather station Vancouver Island Georgia Strait Sometimes go familiarization trips meteorologist example replace calibrate weather sensors hop hovercraft Canadian Coast Guard jealous know background one monitoring technicians three coast guards unload equipment onto platform Cindy YU MSC Crew

caption_original: “It is good to have an end to journey toward; but it is the journey that matters, in the end.” – Ursula K. Le GuinDr. Fred Roots had quite the journey, and we owe him a lot. He lived a life full of eloration and discovery, and he played an influential role in the development of Environment Canada. From organizing the Polar Continental Shelf Program to chairing the UNESCO Man and the Biosphere Programme, his accomplishments were many. Dr. Roots is also known for his contribution in writing the Antarctic Treaty—a treaty whose legacy lives on today. He will always be remembered.:
caption_cleaned: good end journey toward journey matters end Ursula Le Guin nDr Fred Roots quite journey owe lot lived life full exploration discovery played influential role development Environment Canada organizing Polar Continental Shelf Program chairing UNESCO Man Biosphere Programme accomplishments many Dr Roots also known contribution writing Antarctic treaty whose legacy lives today always remembered studentsonice

caption_original: We spotted this oddball heron and her mate nesting on a pylon while surveying the heron population in the Fraser River, BC. Must be something to it, they raised a chick there!

caption_original: Spotted: Our mini van on a field trip for bird conservation to the beautiful Lac du Bois grasslands.

caption_original: “Being biologists, we were out looking for great blue herons again this summer. By visiting nesting sites, we can monitor these awesome birds and track the species. Sadly, their numbers are declining, so we’re learning all we can!” – Kate and Britney, CWS Crew
caption_cleaned: biologists looking great blue herons summer visiting nesting sites monitor awesome birds track species Sadly numbers declining learning Kate Britney CWS Crew

caption_original: You probably know us as Environment Canada, but we’ve been Environment and Climate Change Canada for almost a year now. What do we do? Sure, we give you your weather info so you can plan your days, but we do so much more than that! Stay tuned and find out what we’re all about. We’re giving you access to exclusive behind-the-scenes photos and videos from teams located across our beautiful country.
